"Light of Eothas be upon you, neighbor. Are you looking for survivors?"

Unlike the other survivors you've seen, this young man, despite a haggard look and a set of dirt-smeared, tattered clothes, wears a calm face and speaks with a steady voice.
"Are you one of the Children of the Dawnstars? My friend is looking for someone you may know."
"Yes, actually. My friend is looking for someone we were told might live around here."
"Short lady, about my age. Came from Dyrwood with her son."
"I should be glad to speak to him. Perhaps I can help."
"He isn't here. I'll return with him."
"I see. Very well. Was there anything else?"
"No, I'll be on my way."
"Uh, let's see... freckles. Braids, usually. Punches you in the arm if she likes you, face if not - and that's if you're lucky."
"We're in the right place. You must know her. She has a son about your age."
"Is there someone else we might ask?"
"I don't think you'll have much luck around here. I know all my neighbors."
"You gotta be her son. Got her nose and her freckles."
"You don't have to lie to me kid, I'm a friend of your mother's."
"She hiding from someone? Maybe an ex-lover who gave her the best night of her life?"
"No, I... I misspoke..."
"Forget it. Just tell me something. Your father - you know him?"
"I'm sorry... who are you?"
"Like Edér said, we're friends of your mother's."
"Relax. Edér's a good man. Likes animals."
"We're the last people you're going to see on Eora if you don't start talking."
"I believe my friend here may have had carnal relations with your mother a long time ago."
"Yes, I knew my father, when I was very young. He was a man of strong faith."
"He was lost to us during the Purges, which was how we came to flee here."

"So, you met him."

Bearn nods slowly.

"Well that's- that's great. You had a dad."

A moment passes with Edér staring at Bearn with a strange undulating grimace drawn back across his face. He clears his throat.
"Have to be. You get Elafa mad, you need a god on your side for protection."
"Where's your mother now? Got a lot of catching up to do."

"She passed the Veil, a few years ago. A flu."

Edér's jaw slackens.
"You're protecting her. We understand."
"We're going to find her, whether or not you help us."
"Take my advice. You see someone like me, you tell them whatever they want to know. Got it?"
"Meaning what exactly?"
"She's at church?"
"Maybe you hadn't heard, but Eothas is in a giant adra statue walking along the sea floor."
"I don't think you take my meaning."
"Yes, he walks among us once again, enlisting faithful soldiers. I do believe she is with him."
Edér's face has gone scarlet beneath his farmer's tan. His nostrils pulsate with each heavy breath.

"You lied to us. Said you didn't know her. Expect me to believe this now?"

He takes a short step toward Bearn, who takes two backwards.
"Easy, he lost his mother."
"I don't think anybody'd go looking too hard for this kid if he went missing, Edér."
"It does look like he might be alone here."
"How can he say it so coldly?"

"It's possible her soul has taken a new body by now, but if she was truly blessed, she marches instead beside the Shining God."

The boy's hinted smile brightens, his eyes far away.
"Funny, you wouldn't know it to look at him."
"It's a good thought, but it wouldn't get me anywhere."
"Well he hides his grief pretty well, doesn't he?"
"Nothing cold about it. It's fevered is what it is."
Edér stares the boy down, then turns away with a grunt and a not-worth-it gesture.

"I'm not lying. She's buried on the other side of that hill."

He points northward.

"Don't be troubled by her passing. All souls that march with Eothas receive his warmth and light."

Edér scowls.
"What do you mean 'march with Eothas'?"
"You seem confident in a god who's causing a lot of destruction."
"Who are the Partisans of the Lighted Path?"
"Eothas has come to us twice now. Even oblivion couldn't slow his march."
"We shouldn't have opposed his first coming. He meant to rally us under his banner."
"He destroyed then as he does now."
"Dyrwood acted hastily, I agree."
"We were victims of a quarrel of gods."
"I know a lot of dead Dyrwoodans who'll be relieved to hear that."
"Eothas forced everyone to declare themselves as ally or enemy. Nothing more."
"You got the giant footprint on your back to prove it."
"Usually a good idea to react hastily to an invasion."
"And seeing what we've seen, it's hard to believe they got our best interests at heart."
"Now he marches again and we have a chance to correct our mistake."
"You can't build on broken foundations. Real change needs destruction."
"I trust my god knows better than I do. He knows truths I'll never learn."
"Got that right."

"I was once lost. I struggled as you do now. But the Partisans of the Lighted Path have restored my faith in Eothas."

At this, Edér looks up at Bearn.
"What greater honor than to march in his vanguard?"
"We began as Children of the Dawnstars, separated from each other as we questioned our purpose."

"But then Eothas granted a vision to Gaderian Bosc. Bosc saw an illuminated path lighting the way through a black abyss."

The words fall from his mouth bulky and awkward, as though someone else had stuffed them there.
"And he saw Eothas marching on the path, and Eothas bade him to march alongside."
"And the Shining God told Gaderian Bosc to gather an army of the god's truest followers, and to prepare to lead it into battle."
"You'd think after getting blown up he'd slow down on the battling."
"Who does Eothas intend to battle?"
"How will you join Eothas when he marches beneath the sea?"
"Has this Bosc shown proof of his visions?"
"How could she be gone?"
"We don't know. The end of the path hasn't been revealed to Gaderian Bosc yet."
"But to the faithful, shouldn't matter."
"There'll be a great journey. But we're prepared."
"Gaderian Bosc knows the way."
"Eothas himself has appeared in Deadfire in the form Gaderian Bosc foretold. That's more proof than any of his faithful could ever ask."
"What fortune to be given this opportunity, to know our god in the living world."
"Edér, did you get what you needed here?"
"We can go."
"As you wish."
"We'll be going."
"Right. This Lighted Path fella. Bosc. Sounds interesting."
"There some way I can meet him?"
"He's usually on the move, rallying followers. But the Partisans of the Lighted Path often gather in the temple of Eothas in Neketaka."
"There is an adherent there, Ogne, who initiates new Partisans. No doubt she'd be pleased to help you."

"Eothas needs able soldiers. Even in their elder years."

Edér spits.
"You should consider what Ogne has to say. It might speak to you."
"Farewell."
"Hello again, and blessings of Eothas to you."
"I had something I wanted to ask."
"You spoke of your mother's soul marching with Eothas."
"Tell me again about the Partisans of the Lighted Path."
"We began as Children of the Dawnstars, separated from each other as we questioned our purpose."

"But then Eothas granted a vision to Gaderian Bosc. Bosc saw an illuminated path lighting the way through a black abyss."

The words fall from his mouth bulky and awkward, as though someone else had stuffed them there.
"And he saw Eothas marching on the path, and Eothas bade him to march alongside."
"And the Shining God told Gaderian Bosc to gather an army of the god's truest followers, and to prepare to lead it into battle."

"No, that doesn't sound like anyone."

The young man's face remains smooth, betraying neither surprise nor interest.

The boy just looks at you with an eerie calmness.

Slowly, his mouth opens.
The boy blinks several times. It's unclear if Edér's comment even registers.
"With Elafa, though, it was more like she had carnal relations with you."

"Right. Friends of Elafa's."

No hint of emotion registers on the boy's face.

"Lions, bats, and orlans, to name a few."

Bearn nods without a hint of humor or personality.

"My mother is with Eothas."

There is a trace of a smile that seems to come with the last word.

Edér appears confused.
"Although after he was dead I don't think any of us ever found out why he'd done what he did."
"I am soon to go there myself, in fact."
"Not quite how I've been seeing it. But everyone's open to their own interpretations."
"I'm not sure what you want to talk about."

Edér takes a deep breath. He looks around, then at Bearn. 

He nods, tight-lipped.
"Hey, uh, kid. What was your name again?"
"Bearn."
"I have my life, and I know it's because of you. I know I should be thanking you."
"But the truth is, I don't know if I want to be here now. Or what I'm supposed to be doing."
"And I still don't know what to say to Eothas when I meet him one day."
"Not in much of a mood to talk, if you don't mind."

"It should be the other way around. He's the one owes you an explanation."

Bearn avoids Edér's gaze.

"You hear me, kid? He owes you."

Bearn gives an absent nod, still looking down, and says no more.
"Well that's charitable."
"I would like to have joined him when he passed this way, but I was weak. It won't happen again."
"Why did you lie to us about knowing Elafa?"
"Gaderian Bosc warned us. Those outside the Partisans may ridicule us and test our faith."
"Especially our old families, and others close to them."
"We've learned it's best to keep to ourselves and those with open minds. Which relations and friends mostly aren't."

Edér looks up expectantly as Bearn disembarks [Player Ship] without a word to anyone. 

Bearn begins to head off, staring straight ahead with sunken eyes, and doesn't break stride when he passes Edér.

"Bearn?"

The boy has taken another several steps before he seems to have heard anything at all, and when he stops, he doesn't turn to face Edér at first, as though keeping his options open. 

A long moment passes, then, with persisting hesitation, he turns.
